text: Speaking of random: Donald Knuth's introduction to the Random Number chapter of his classic "The Art of Computer Programming" should be required reading.  (Who am I kidding? The entire series probably should be!)

My parents got it as a gift when I got into university, because I kept going to the national library to sit in the reference section to read it.

But that chapter has quite interesting insights, but I remember it had fairly little in the way of generating numbers from a distribution.

text: Yeah, it is kinda textbook expensive, but in terms of computer books it has had (and will continue to have IMHO) a very long shelf life.  In terms of monetary-unit-per-shelf-year it's not much worse than other books I've long since recycled. (But how many people buy physical books anymore?)

text: The Random Numbers chapter has some discussions about generating numbers from various distributions (including generic approaches for any "well behaved" PDF), but its main focus is definitely more on the "randomness" aspect.  It has a mix of both the practical (for the time?) and the theoretical.

text: Another book with a worthwhile Random Numbers chapter is "Numerical Recipes".  It has one of my favorite quotes on this topic, from a computer center's programming consultant explaining/defending the incredibly flawed `RANDU` function: "We guarantee that each number is random individually, but we don't guarantee that more than one of them is random." :zany_face::exploding_head::face_with_rolling_eyes:

text: It's really good, but volume 2 really could use a new addition. Some of the stuff on random numbers isn't the most up to date. (It spends a lot of time on LCGs which are really bad). It also spends a lot of time on how to do Floating point arithmatic in hardware, which isn't the most useful anymore.
